properties.name: Accessibility
properties.notes:
Accessibility https://www.nps.gov/places/accessibility.htm

Carlsbad Caverns National Park offers accessible parking, picnicking, dining, and visitor center services.

Please review our Accessibility Guide.

Service Animals

Please visit our Service Animals information page.

Experience Carlsbad Cavern

The park offers elevator service into and out of the cavern, where you can access the Big Room Trail.

The Big Room Trail is the only wheelchair accessible route in the cavern. You will discover this one mile (2 km) trail after you descend 750 feet (229 m) into the Underground Rest Area. Please note the trail is wet from dripping water and can be slippery, bumpy, uneven, and difficult to navigate. It is not Americans with Disabilities Act approved and should only be attempted with assistance. Maps defining the wheelchair accessible areas can be obtained in the visitor center. Due to steep grades and narrowness of the trail, barriers, and signs have been installed to note the portions that are inaccessible in a wheelchair.

The Natural Entrance Trail is not Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) compliant due to its steep grade (15%–20%) and therefore not accessible with wheelchairs.

Strollers: Strollers, baby carriages, and similar devices are prohibited in all caves except as necessary for children with mobility issues. If medically needed, they are allowed within the wheelchair-designated portions of the Big Room of Carlsbad Cavern, but never on the Natural Entrance trail due to the steep grade.

Segways: Segways and similar large mobility devices are prohibited in all caves. Cave conditions pose an unacceptable hazard to the safety of the operators of such devices due to narrow trails, cave ceiling variations, and steep inclines.

Wheelchairs/Devices That Aid Walking: Wheelchairs, walkers, scooters and similar devices are permitted in the wheelchair-designated portions of the Big Room only and not in other areas of the cavern or any other caves.

Canes/Walking Sticks: The possession and/or use of a walking stick within the cavern is prohibited, except for those individuals with limited mobility that are medically necessary. Visitors with canes/walking sticks must only use them on the paved trail and are required to have a rubber or soft tip.

Ranger-led tours are not accessible with wheelchairs, walkers, scooters, or canes due to difficult and rugged trail conditions. Exception: You may use a cane or walking stick on the King's Palace tour if medically needed, but no wheelchairs, walkers, or scooters.

Park Brochure Audio Description

The park brochure is audio described and can be listened to on the Publications page.

Park Brochure in Large Print Format

The park brochure is available in large print at the visitor center information desk or can be downloaded.

Audio Guide

The Western National Parks Association store, located in the visitor center, offers audio guides for rent that provide information that is interesting and educational as you walk through the cavern. The script is also available for download to your personal device.

Bat Flight Program

Reserved, accessible parking is available in the "Bat Flight Disabled Parking" area. Please look for the brown sign with the wheelchair icon before you arrive at the visitor center. The very upper row of the Bat Flight Amphitheater features a reserved area for visitors using wheelchairs. A family style accessible restroom is also available.

Visitor Center Parking

Accessible parking is marked with blue reserved signs. The visitor center, theater, gift shop, bookstore, restrooms, and restaurant can be accessed via ramps from the parking lot. You may enter the visitor center via automatic doors in the front.

Picnic Areas

Accessible picnic tables near the visitor center are located at the far end of the east parking lot as well as south of the restaurant. A few tables can be found along Walnut Canyon Drive—the main paved road from the park entrance.

Nature Trail

A section of the outdoor nature trail near the visitor center is partially accessible to wheelchairs. The trailhead is located in the east parking lot. Please ask a ranger at the visitor centerinformation desk for more details.

Rattlesnake Springs Picnic Area

Located about 15 miles (24 km) from the visitor center, this grassy area features picnic tables and cooking grills under large cottonwood trees. Accessible restrooms and an accessible picnic table are available.

Walnut Canyon Desert Drive

A one-hour drive through the Chihuahuan Desert, this low speed, 9.5 mile (15 km) gravel road is suitable for most vehicles except motor homes and cars pulling trailers. The Walnut Canyon Desert Drive begins near the visitor center and a brochure is available upon request at the visitor center information desk.

Roadside Exhibits

Interpretive signs and bulletin boards are located at pull-outs along the park entrance road. Most are readable from your vehicle.

Additional Information

  • The park does not rent or loan any type of mobility assistance equipment (canes, wheelchairs, or scooters). Wheelchairs, scooters, walkers, rubber tipped canes, and walking sticks needed for medical purposes are permitted in the cavern, but recreational walking or hiking sticks (or any kind of stick with a sharp, pointy end) are not permitted.

  • Please use careful consideration when deciding to walk down the Natural Entrance Trail if you have medical issues such as painful knees, hips, ankles or feet, trouble walking, a heart condition, breathing problems, issues climbing stairs, problems with balance, and/or difficulty seeing in dim light.

  • Consider that the Big Room has inclines and declines along the walking path. If your mobility is limited, please plan accordingly.

  • Small oxygen tanks are permitted in the cavern for medical reasons. Ensure you have plenty of oxygen and new batteries for your time in the cavern. If you have breathing problems, you may want to bring a personal inhaler with you due to high humidity in the cavern.

  • Flashlights and helmets with headlamps are permitted in the cavern.

properties.name: Bienvenido a Carlsbad Caverns National Park
properties.notes:
Bienvenido a Carlsbad Caverns National Park https://www.nps.gov/places/bienvenido.htm

A medida que atraviesa el desierto de Chihuahua y las montañas de Guadalupe, al sudeste de New Mexico y Texas occidental—llenado de tunas, chollas, sotoles y agaves—nunca podría imaginarse que existen más do 300 cuevas conocidas por debajo de la superficie. El parque nacional cuenta con 122 de cuevas, formadas cuando el ácido sulfúrico disolvió la piedra caliza de los alrededores y creo algunas de las cavernas más grandes en los Estados Unidos.

Planifique su visita

La visita a Carlsbad Caverns National Park se disfruta más cuando se planifica con antelación. Para hacer reservaciones, hágalo en Recreation.gov o llame al 877-444-6777. 

Para estudiantes y grupales (grupos de exploración, organizaciones y clubes cívicos o de interés especial y grupos parroquiales, etc.) el parque requiere acompañantes responsables que vayan con el grupo. Como mínimo debe traer un acompañante adulto par cada diez menores de estudiantes.

¿Qué Hacer?

Desde el último de mayo hasta el último de octubre los visitantes del parque nacional pueden disfrutar un nocturno del vuelo de murciélagos.

Visitantes al parque deben visitar la sección principal de la cueva, el recorrido bello y fácil para caminar el Big Room (la gran sala). El recorrido Natural Entrance (entrada natural) también es muy impresionante, pero no se recomienda a visitantes con problemas de salud porque está muy difícil para caminar por muy escarpado.

Debido al COVID-19 todas guidas de guarda parque están suspendidas hasta nuevo aviso. Hay disponibles varias visitas por la caverna de dos recorridos auto guiadas del Big Room (Gran Sala) y Natural Entrance (Entrada Natural).

Las cuevas son lugares increíbles para los niños curiosos una pregunta que se escucha con frecuencia de la caverna es "¿A dónde va ese agujero?" ¡Participe en los recorridos auto guiadas de Carlsbad Caverns! se rentan por cinco dólares en la biblioteca del parque.

¡Puede acompañarnos en el programa nocturno del vuelo de murciélagos o convertiste en joven guardaparque. Estas son excelentes maneras de descubrir lo que tiene de especial este parque nacional! Para obtener más información, visite el mostrador de información en el centro de visitantes.Horario Normal durante COVID-19El centro de visitante y la caverna están cerrados en el día de Acción de Gracias Dia de Navidad y el día del año nuevo.

Centro de Visitantes
8 am–5 pm

El ultimo boleto de entrada a la caverna se vende a las
2:15 pm

2:30 pm

4:45 pm

Última vez para salir de la caverna

Precios y reservaciones

Precios de entrada:

Adultos: $15                                                                                                                         
Para reservar en recreation.gov es $1 para asegurar su reservación. El centro de visitante es cuando compra su boleto para entrar a la caverna.

Personas menores de 15 años gratis.

Todas personas que ingresa a Carlsbad Caverns National Park, para cualquier visita deben pagar por boleto un costo para entrar. Este boleto es válido por tres días consecutivo.

"America the Beautiful" pases para parques nacionales y terrenos federales recreativos son aceptados. Los pases son Annual, Senior, Access, y Volunteer. Estos pases permiten entrada al titular de la tarjeta y tres adultos. Parques que cobran por carro los pases permite a todos en el carro.

Guiadas con un guardaparque están temporalmente suspendidas al debido al COVID-19.   

King's Palace (Palacio del Rey): $8 por adulto, $4 por niños 4-15 años. No se permiten niños menores de 4 años. Estos costos son en adición del costo de la entrada. El costo para los titulares del pase de Senior y Access es $4

Left Hand Tunnel: El costo es $7 por adulto y $3.50 por niño. Ne se permite niños menores de 6 años. Estos costos son en adición del costo de la entrada. El costo para los titulares de pase del Senior y Access es $3.50

Slaughter Canyon Cave: El costo es $15 por adulto y $7.50 por niño. Ne se permite niños menores de 8 años. El costo para los titulares de pase del Senior y Access es $7.50

Lower Cave: El costo es $20 por adulto y $10.00 por niño. Ne se permite niños menores de 12 años. Estos costos son en adición del costo de la entrada. El costo para los titulares de pase del Senior y Access es $10.00

Hall of the White Giant: El costo es $20 por adulto y $10.00 por niño. Ne se permite niños menores de 12 años. Estos costos son en adición del costo de la entrada. El costo para los titulares de pase del Senior y Access es $10.00

Condiciones para acampar en el interior agreste

Acampar
Solo se permite acampar en el interior agreste de Carlsbad Caverns National Park. Todos los usuarios del interior agreste deben obtener un permiso de uso en el centro de visitantes. Solo se permite acampar en el interior agreste al oeste de la entrada del sendero de Rattlesnake Canyon, cerca del camino Desert Scenic Loop y al sur del sendero Guadalupe Ridge. Acampar en el límite del parque, por aproximadamente 2 millas (3 km) después de donde es permitido acampar tanto al norte como al sur del sendero.

Las áreas de acampar deben estar al menos a 100 pies (30 m) de los senderos establecidos a 300 pies (90 m) de cualquier fuente de agua o entrada de caverna y a 0.5 millas o 2,600 pies (792 m) de cualquier carretera o estacionamiento.

El máximo de personas por grupos acampano en el interior agreste es 10. Los grupos más grandes deben caminar y acampar a lo menos 0.25 millas (400 m) de las áreas apartadas.

El titular de permiso debe tener 18 años o más.La estadía máxima es de 7 noches consecutivas.

Se prohíbe acampar en vehículos o caravanas. No se permite acampar en ninguna otra área incluso a lo largo de las carreteras en estacionamientos o en entradas de sendero.

Otras cosas que debe tener cuenta

No altere ni recoja plantas, animales, minerales, ni objetos culturales.

Está prohibido el ingreso al interior agreste sin permiso escrito del superintendente.

El sendero Guadalupe Ridge está abierto al uso de caballos o animales de carga. Cualquier campamento de más de una noche requiere un permiso de campo.

Informe todos los accidentes, incendios, lesiones, personas pérdidas u otras emergencias al guardaparques.

Se prohíbe el uso de bicicletas de montaña y vehículo motorizados en todos los senderos del parque.

Cierre y atranque su vehículo y llevase todo de valor.

Accesibilidad

Animales de servicio
Los perros que están entrenados para trabajar o realizar tareas para personas con incapacidad están permitidos en el Big Room, senderos de la Natural Entrance, el King’s Palace y en el anfiteatro. Bajo la ley de los Estados Unidos…Los perros de terapia o de apoyo emocional no se consideran animales de servicio y, por lo tanto, no están permitidos en la caverna.

Viajando con mascotas

El servicio de la perrera está disponible en el Centro de Visitantes. No se permiten mascotas en la Cavernas fuera de la carretea, en anfiteatro o en senderos sin pavimentar.

Guidas de audio

Solicite información sobre el audio guía que son muy informativos e están disponible para alquilar por $5 en la librería de Western National Parks Association. Puede escuchar este audio recorrido mientras camina por la caverna, parada por parada, escuchando información sobre la caverna que es interesante y educativa. Los idiomas disponibles, incluyen, español, inglés, alemán, japonés, y chino mandarín. Puede comunicarse con la libraría de asociaciones de Carlsbad Caverns al 575-785-1085.

Clima

Las condiciones del tiempo en el sudeste de New Mexico pueden cambiar rápidamente en cualquier momento del ano. En el invierno el suele puede ser frio y seco, con nieve y tormentas de hielo ocasionales. La primavera extremadamente ventosa. El verano es muy caloroso y las violentas tormentas eléctricas son comunes por las noches. El otoño generalmente es templado y sin extremos.

Obviamente la temperatura en la cueva es de 56°F (13°C) todo el año. Una chaqueta liviana y zapatos cómodos con suela de goma son adecuados y recomendados todo el año.

Voluntarios (en el parque)


El programa de voluntarios está suspendido hasta nuevo aviso.

Voluntarios vienen de todo el mundo para preservar y proteger (la herencia naturales y cultural herencia) de los parques nacionales en los Estados Unidos, para que esta generación y generaciones futuros pueden disfrutar.

La protección, preservación e interpretación de los excelentes recursos de Carlsbad Caverns National Park no serían posibles sin la ayuda de los voluntarios. El coordinador de voluntarios llame al número de informaciones para preguntar de tiempos para poder se voluntario.

Carlsbad Caverns National Park                                       
3225 National Parks Highway
Carlsbad, New Mexico 88220

Teléfono   

Información general sobre el parque
575-785-2232

Información sobre el vuelo de murciélagos
575-236-1374

Direcciones

Los visitantes llegan por la carretera principal US62/180 desde Carlsbad, New Mexico (23 millas/37 km al noreste) o desde El Paso, Texas (150 millas/24 km al oeste). Una carretera de entrada escénica de 7 millas (11 km) conduce desde la entrada del parque en White's City hasta el centro de visitantes y la entrada de las cavernas.

properties.name: Brantley Lake State Park
properties.notes:
Brantley Lake State Park https://www.nps.gov/places/brantley-lake-state-park.htm The southernmost lake in New Mexico is an oasis of water, wildlife, and plant life. Located 12 miles (19.3 km) north of Carlsbad, New Mexico, the state park offers boating, kayaking, canoeing, fishing, hiking trails, bird watching, developed and primitive campsites, and restrooms with showers.

For fees, hours, and other information:
575-457-2384
Website

properties.name: Carlsbad Cavern
properties.notes:
Carlsbad Cavern https://www.nps.gov/places/carlsbad-cavern.htm

Explore Carlsbad Cavern at your own pace on the Big Room and Natural Entrance trails. Access is available by elevator or hiking.

 

Reservations Required to Enter Cavern

  • Reservations must be purchased online or by calling 877-444-6777.

  • The reservation is only for selecting the entry time.

  • Entrance tickets will need to be purchased at the visitor center.

 

Big Room Trail

The most popular route, the Big Room, is the largest single cave chamber by volume in North America. This 1.25 mile (2 km) trail is relatively flat, and will take about 1.5 hours (on average) to walk it. Actor and comedian Will Rogers called the cavern, "The Grand Canyon with a roof over it." You will be rewarded with spectacular views, cave formations of all shapes and sizes, and a rope ladder used by explorers in 1924.

If you are seeking a shorter experience, the Big Room has a shortcut which reduces the walking distance to about 0.6 miles (1 km). The hiking time is about 45 minutes.

Parts of the Big Room Trail are wheelchair accessible. You can ask for more information about accessibility at the visitor center. You may also download our Accessibility Brochure [0.5 MB PDF].
 

Natural Entrance Trail

The 1.25 mile (2 km) Natural Entrance Trail is extremely steep. Depending on if you decide to hike up or down, you gain or lose about 750 feet (229 m)—equivalent to walking up or down a 75-story building. The hike takes about one hour (on average) to complete. This trail is not recommended for visitors with heart or respiratory conditions.

You have the opportunity to follow in the footsteps of early explorers as you see formations like Devil's Spring, the Whale's Mouth, and Iceberg Rock.

The Natural Entrance is not an accessible trail.

properties.name: First-Time Visitors
properties.notes:
First-Time Visitors https://www.nps.gov/places/first-time-visitors.htm

Click the links below for more information.

Reservation Required to Enter Cavern

  • Reservations must be purchased online or by calling 877-444-6777.
  • No reservations available at the park.
  • Reservations are only for selecting the entry time.
  • Upon arrival at the visitor center, entrance tickets must be purchased.
     

Alerts and Conditions

How to Get to the Park

Operating Hours: Visitor Center and Cavern

Entrance Fee
$15 per person (ages 16 and older)
Free (ages 15 and younger)
Free with National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Passes

Enjoy the Cavern at Your Own Pace
The entrance fee includes access to the enjoy, on your own, the majority of Carlsbad Cavern along the Big Room and Natural Entrance trails. Access is available by elevator or hiking.

Ranger-Guided Tours
Temporarily suspended until further notice.

Audio Guides
Informative audio guides are available to rent at the Western National Parks Association store in the visitor center.

Footwear in the Cavern
Some areas of the Big Room and Natural Entrance trails are wet from natural water drips and steep. For safety, closed-toe shoes with good traction (e.g. lug soles) are recommended. Flip flops, sandals, and some walking shoes have little or no traction and increase the possibility of slips, trips, and falls. Watch your step and use the handrails when necessary. For some ranger-guided tours, hiking boots or hiking shoes with good aggressive tread are required.

Lighting in the Cavern
The cavern is dimly lit. You are welcome to bring a flashlight or headlamp, but it is not necessary.

Bio-Cleaning Mats Help Protect Bats
All visitors who enter the cavern are required to walk on bio-cleaning mats after exiting. This extraordinary measure is due to the potential presence of the fungus which causes White-Nose Syndrome in New Mexico.

Online Bookstore

Food and Drinks
Limited options are available at the visitor center from 8 am to 4 pm daily.

Bat Flight Program
Each evening from late-May through October, enjoy a ranger program about the Brazilian free-tailed bats that live in Carlsbad Cavern and see them emerge. To protect the bats, electronic devices are not allowed at the Bat Flight Program and surrounding area. Electronic devices include cameras of any kind, laptop computers, cell phones, iPads, iPods, tablets, and MP3 players.

Service Animals
Dogs that are trained to do work or perform tasks for people with dis­abilities are permitted in the Big Room and Natural Entrance trails, King's Palace, and the Bat Flight Amphitheater. Under the Americans with Disabilities Act, therapy or emotional support dogs are not considered service animals and therefore are not permitted in the cavern.

Accessibility

Traveling with Pets
Pets are not allowed in the cavern, on unpaved park trails on the surface, off road, during the Bat Flight Program, or in the visitor center. Pets may not be left unattended in a vehicle. A kennel is available at the visitor center.

Other Things to Know Before You Visit

Frequently Asked Questions

Publications

properties.name: Lincoln National Forest
properties.notes:
Lincoln National Forest https://www.nps.gov/places/lincoln-national-forest.htm The forest encompasses 1,103,441 acres for hiking, caving, camping, picnicking, horseback riding, hunting, and sightseeing.

Maps are available at the Guadalupe Ranger District Office located at 5203 Buena Vista Drive, Carlsbad, New Mexico.

For fees, maps, and other information:
Guadalupe Ranger District Office
5203 Buena Vista Drive
Carlsbad, NM 88220
575-885-4181
Forest Service website

properties.name: Living Desert Zoo & Gardens State Park
properties.notes:
Living Desert Zoo & Gardens State Park https://www.nps.gov/places/living-desert-zoo-gardens-state-park.htm Experience the many habitats of the Chihuahuan Desert on a 1.3 mile (2.1 km) self-guiding tour of the zoo. See various native fauna including the rare Mexican gray wolf, cougars, and the roadrunner, and a large collection of cacti and succulents from around the world.

For fees, hours, and other information:
575-887-5516
Website

properties.name: Natural Entrance to Carlsbad Cavern
properties.notes:
Natural Entrance to Carlsbad Cavern https://www.nps.gov/places/cavern-natural-entrance.htm Enjoy the view of the Natural Entrance from the Bat Flight Amphitheater. This was the only access to Carlsbad Cavern before elevators were installed in the 1930s.

To hike into the Natural Entrance, reservations are required and must be purchased online or by calling 877-444-6777.

properties.name: Rattlesnake Springs
properties.notes:
Rattlesnake Springs https://www.nps.gov/places/rattlesnake-springs.htm

Rattlesnake Springs, part of Carlsbad Caverns National Park, is a lush oasis in the desert. This riparian ecosystem features a natural spring and a large grove of cottonwood trees planted by the Civilian Conservation Corps. It’s an ideal place for bird watching year round.

Rattlesnake Springs is a day use area only, open during daylight hours. It includes a picnic area with shaded picnic tables and cooking grills, trash cans, and pit toilets. Swimming is not allowed in the spring.

Accessiblity: Restrooms and picnic table are available.

properties.name: Reservations Required to Enter Cavern
properties.notes:
Reservations Required to Enter Cavern https://www.nps.gov/places/reservations-to-enter-cavern.htm
  • Reservations must be purchased online or by calling 877-444-6777.
  • The reservation is only for selecting the entry time.
  • Entrance tickets will need to be purchased at the visitor center.

properties.name: Sitting Bull Falls Recreation Area
properties.notes:
Sitting Bull Falls Recreation Area https://www.nps.gov/places/sitting-bull-falls-recreation-area.htm

This desert oasis features a series of spring-fed waterfalls that fall 150 feet (45.7 m) to a large pool of water below. There is an ADA accessible path to the falls viewing area a short distance from the parking lot, along with several hiking trails. Sheltered picnic sites with tables and grills are available, along with fresh water, trash cans, and restrooms. 

Sitting Bull Falls Recreation Area is 42 miles (67.6 km) west of Carlsbad, New Mexico, and can be reached via two routes. From north of Carlsbad, take Highway 137 from US 285, and then follow Forest Road 276. From south of Carlsbad, take Dark Canyon Road/County Road 408 from US 62/180, and then follow Forest Road 276. 


For fees, hours, and other information:
575-885-4181
Website
